Hi Derek,

Derek James wrote:

>We talked a bit about the format for run XML a while
>back, but we're running into the issue of network (or
>phenotype) XML.
>
>We've revamped our neural network framework to more
>logically work with NEAT, and basically there is no
>concept of layers in a NEAT phenotype (other than
>input and output).  We have graphical tools that lay
>out our raw chromosome XML in a spiral pattern, but
>while it looks kind of cool, it isn't very readable.
>  
>
>So if we have a network, evolved with NEAT, that has
>10 input nodes, 10 output nodes, and 35 hidden nodes,
>with dozens of connections (self, recurrent, and
>forward), how does it make the most sense to:
>  
>
>--Represent this phenotype in XML?
>--Graphically represent this phenotype?
>
>  
>
Normally I would resist placing extra data into an XML dialect that 
could be inferred from other data, it's effectibely redundant. However I 
understand it may be a pain to do complex logic in XSLT and as such I 
think it's reasonable to define, say, an attribute on neuron tags such 
as hintLayer="1". Infact a number of different hint* attributes might be 
useful for different types of representations. I think these sort of 
'hint' attributes should be defined as being optional though. We would 
would then be able to take existing phenotype XML and pass it through a 
network structure analysis tool - analysing the 'core' XML and 
annotating it with hint* attributes. If you want to define a new type of 
visualisation then just create your own hint* tags, update the tool and 
the XML will still conform to the dialect definition (XSD).


>Should the neuron tags also include an attribute
>assigning them to a particular layer?  We use XSL to
>parse the XML into SVG, and in and of itself, XSL
>really isn't useful for determining layout logic. 
>It's best to have the layout structure inherent in the
>XML.
>
>  
>
Had you thought about the best way to determine the layer? I guess you 
could calculate the shortest number of 'hops' for each hidden neuron to 
an input neuron? Trouble is you might end up with all of the neurons in 
layer 1 !!


Colin
